bug.author: rxng8
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h4>Issue description</denchmark-h>
When I compile with data::Load function to load csv, it cannot compile. <denchmark-h:h4>Your environment</denchmark-h>
version of mlpack: 3.4.2 operating system: Ubuntu 20 compiler: g++ version of dependencies (Boost/Armadillo): any other environment information you think is relevant:
<denchmark-h:h4>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>
main.cpp: <denchmark-code>#include <mlpack/core.hpp> using namespace mlpack; // Our dataset matrix, which is column-major.
int main() { arma::mat data; // Use data::Load() which transposes the matrix. data::Load("data.csv", data, true); } </denchmark-code>
Compiling: <denchmark-code>g++ ./main.cpp -o main -std=c++11 -Wall -Wextra -O3 -DNDEBUG -fopenmp -lmlpack </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h4>Expected behavior</denchmark-h>
It should compile <denchmark-h:h4>Actual behavior</denchmark-h>
Log: <denchmark-code>/tmp/cc78ulEv.o: in function `main': main.cpp:(.text.startup+0x88): undefined reference to `bool mlpack::data::Load<double>(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char,std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, arma::Mat<double>&, bool, bool, arma::file_type)' collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status </denchmark-code>

comments.comment: I'm able to compile that fine on my system with mlpack-3.4.2 (I'm running debian sid). But I was actually just exchanging emails with another user who seems to have the same issue. What compiler version are you using? For me: <denchmark-code>$ g++ --version g++ (Debian 9.3.0-15) 9.3.0 Copyright (C) 2019 Free Software Foundation, Inc. This is free software; see the source for copying conditions. There is NO warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. </denchmark-code>

Hey <denchmark-link:https://github.com/rxng8>@rxng8</denchmark-link> , I think the problem here is that you are not linking mlpack while compiling. Add to the compilation command and that should probably work. Hey <denchmark-link:https://github.com/rcurtin>@rcurtin</denchmark-link> , I feel its a bit of extra work to manually link mlpack while compiling any program. Can you please tell how do you do it without linking on your system?

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/RishabhGarg108>@RishabhGarg108</denchmark-link> Hi, appreciate your reply, as you can see on the report above that when I produce this error, I add as the last argument. I don't know if that help. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/rcurtin>@rcurtin</denchmark-link> I use the same g++ version as you: <denchmark-code>g++ (Ubuntu 9.3.0-17ubuntu1~20.04) 9.3.0 Copyright (C) 2019 Free Software Foundation, Inc. This is free software; see the source for copying conditions. There is NO warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. </denchmark-code>
Additional information:
I built the mlpack v3.4.2 from source, using cMake and make. I install the buid by make install, and did export the path where the include library is. I am running ubuntu in Window subsystem, not the whole Ubuntu operating system.
I hope that helps!
Sorry, my bad. Somehow missed that last flag.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/rxng8>@rxng8</denchmark-link> is it possible that there are multiple versions of mlpack installed on your system? Maybe a /usr/lib/libmlpack.so and also a /usr/local/lib/libmlpack.so?
Try this before compilation: export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/path/to/libmlpack.so
Refer to <denchmark-link:https://github.com/mlpack/mlpack#4-building-mlpack-from-source>this</denchmark-link>

I am experiencing the same problem and I have been communicating with Ryan via e-mail about it. I have just tried to add "export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/path/to/libmlpack.so" before compiling the program, but unfortunately that didn't work.
Just to clarify, in my case the problem is specifically with the method "data::Load". If I comment it out, I can compile my program (which includes several layers of DNN) without any problem.
Hi <denchmark-link:https://github.com/InterTriplete2010>@InterTriplete2010</denchmark-link> , can you please share the error?

Sure, of course. DNN.cpp:(.text+0x6fa): undefined reference to `bool mlpack::data::Load(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, arma::Mat&, bool, bool, arma::file_type)' collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
Can you also share the code maybe I can try reproducing the error ?
Can you please share the code file (maybe .cpp). This text is tough to copy and read

Yes, sorry. I had to zip it, because github would not allow me to upload a cpp file. Let me know if you can download it. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/mlpack/mlpack/files/5538427/DNN.zip>DNN.zip</denchmark-link>
I am able to download

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/InterTriplete2010>@InterTriplete2010</denchmark-link> sorry that I didn't get back to your email yet---but since this issue seems the same, we can keep the discussion going here. To me it's very strange why your compiler is not able to find the data::Load symbol. What happens if you also include mlpack/core/data/load_impl.hpp in your program? Also, if you are on Linux, what is the output of this command? nm -D libmlpack.so | c++filt | grep 'data::Load' (You'll have to update that so that it points to the correct libmlpack.so.) It'll be a lot of output---it's all the symbols in libmlpack.so that have data::Load as part of them. But we should at least be able to see whether the symbol we're looking for is even in the library.
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/rcurtin>@rcurtin</denchmark-link> when I build form source using in a Linux system, will appear in any path? And which path does that usually installed to?
It should usually install to /usr/local/lib/. On most systems, that should be on the default linker path.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/rcurtin>@rcurtin</denchmark-link> Thank you for your help :-) I tried to include mlpack/core/data/load_impl.hpp in my code, but that didn't solve the problem. I have pasted the output that I get by using nm -D libmlpack.so | c++filt | grep 'data::Load. Something that I just realized is that I have 3 different libmlpack and 2 different python in my usr/local/lib folder: cmake libmlpack.so libmlpack.so.3 libmlpack.so.3.4 python2.7 python3.8 Is this expected, or is this creating some sort of problems? Thank you!!! Alex.
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/InterTriplete2010>@InterTriplete2010</denchmark-link> These should be symbolic references. Can you paste here the output of the following commands: in

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/InterTriplete2010>@InterTriplete2010</denchmark-link> Thanks Are these giving an output?
It is taking a while to install locate

Wow, that is not what I expected to see. Check out this line from <denchmark-link:https://github.com/InterTriplete2010>@InterTriplete2010</denchmark-link> 's output: <denchmark-code>00000000000d2ad0 W bool mlpack::data::Load(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, arma::Mat&, bool, bool, arma::file_type) </denchmark-code>
But there is no template parameter like there should be! Note that arma::Mat is itself not a type---it needs a template parameter. Compare that with what I get on my local system: <denchmark-code>0000000000577782 W bool mlpack::data::Load<double>(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, arma::Mat<double>&, bool, bool, arma::file_type) </denchmark-code>
I tried to reproduce this in an Ubuntu 20.04 docker container, using both g++ and clang as compilers, and ld and gold as linkers. And I couldn't produce a without the template parameter. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/InterTriplete2010>@InterTriplete2010</denchmark-link> is there any chance that you can rebuild mlpack with and paste all of the output? Then also, from your build directory, . It will be long... I want to see if somehow there is some different flag at link time for libmlpack.so.

Sure, of course. I will do it now. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/InterTriplete2010>@InterTriplete2010</denchmark-link>
You have two mlpack versions installed, the first installed via and the second installed manually. If is empty, then the compiler will try to link with the older version if you are using headers from 3.4 and linking with 3.2 then this might be an issue. The best is to remove mlpack completely from your system, Then you can follow with <denchmark-link:https://github.com/rcurtin>@rcurtin</denchmark-link> solution.

Oh... I think you are exactly right <denchmark-link:https://github.com/shrit>@shrit</denchmark-link> ! Nice catch. Once you , you might need to add to your linker flags (that directory may or may not be in the library search path). Looks like the template parameter is still now showing up in the new version. But before digging further let's see if this is a "multiple versions of mlpack" issue. :)

Yes, that was the problem. Now everything is compiling just fine. I am not sure how I was able to install two versions of mlpack. I followed the instructions online, but I have obviously done something really stupid. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/shrit>@shrit</denchmark-link> and <denchmark-link:https://github.com/rcurtin>@rcurtin</denchmark-link> thank you so much for your help :-) I really appreciate the time you have dedicated to help me out!!! Hopefully, I won't need to bother you again :-) But I have the feeling I will.....

No worries <denchmark-link:https://github.com/InterTriplete2010>@InterTriplete2010</denchmark-link> ! Sometimes issues like this are hard to track down because the linker doesn't give great output. If you have more problems in the future, please do feel free to post issues.

has the same problem after I build with mlpack-3.4.2 from source code in linux 18.04. linux 18.04 has very old version of mlpack like 2.2.5, I have to build mlpack-3.4.2 myself and remove mlpack-2.2.5 totally.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/xiandong79>@xiandong79</denchmark-link> if you have this problem, make sure that you remove any mlpack version you installed via . You could also file a bug in the Ubuntu bug trackers asking them to backport a modern version of mlpack. I've done this in the past, but never heard back.

I have tried to run the same code on my manjaro system and got this error : /usr/bin/ld: /usr/lib/libarmadillo.so.9: undefined reference to `H5Ovisit' collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status I had got the same error while building mlpack from source but I was able to fix it by reinstalling armadillo. How can I fix this without having to do that every time? if necessary I can provide the output for ls -la in /usr/local/bin locate libmlpack echo $LD_LIBRARY_PATH

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/PranavReddyP16>@PranavReddyP16</denchmark-link> I'm assuming that you're getting this error while compiling a C++ program that uses mlpack. It looks to me like maybe you just need to add to your linker options. Also, I am not sure if this is already what you've done, but I'd recommend installing Armadillo via your package manager (that way we are ensured that the HDF5 dependencies are installed and set up correctly).
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had any recent activity. It will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions!
